Gave interview to Bombay Chronicle on train; reached Bombay; addressed public meeting; Sailed for London by s.s. Rajputana to attend Round Table Conference. With him sailed Malaviya, Mrs. Naidu, Prabhashankar Pattani, Mahadev Desai, Pyarelal, Devadas, Mirabehn, and G.D. Birla.
Appealed to Indian people to preserve absolutely non-violent atmosphere during absence and follow constructive programme.
Reached Aden; gave interview to Reuter; was presented address and purse at reception in reply to which he said that free India could be a great force of service to whole of mankind.
Gandhi reached Port Said; in interview to Cairo's Al Ahram, said if RTC failed consequences would be resumption of civil disobedience movement.
Urged Egyptian nationalists to fight non-violently; in special interview to The Daily Telegraph, said he would not be a party to anysettlement subjugating any community to another in India.
Received Mustafa Nahas Pasha's welcome message inviting him to visit Egypt on his homeward journey.
Expressed disappointment on arrival at Port Siad as large number of admmirers were prevented by authorities from meeting him.
In interview on board ship said he had prepared no plans, no speeches, no arguments and no programme for his stay in London.
Landed at Marseilles; was received by Madeleine Rolland on behalf of her brother, Romain Rolland who was ill.
Told Pressmen: "I am going to England to realize the dream of my life-the freedom of my country."
In interview to The New York Times said he had no intention of visiting the United States as he believed he was "not wanted" there.
In another interview to Press said he would, provided he was invited to, go to Lancashire even if he was to be lynched.
Left at 4.30 p.m. by P. and O. Express for Calais.
In interview to the Press gave essece of Congress mandate.
In broadcast to America from Columbia Broadcasting Service made an appeal to conscience of the people. Met British Prime Minister and Lord Sankey.
Attended Federal Structure Committee meeting but did not speak, it being his Silence Day.
At Federal Structure Committee presented national demand of Complete Independence.
Speaking at meeting of Labour M.P.s reiterated India's dermand for Complete Independence.
Gave interview to the Textile Mercury and News Chronicle.
Spoke at Federal Structure Committee on elections of members of Federal Legislature.
Spoke at Reception at Kingsley Hall.
Shifted to 88 Knightsbridge from Kingsley Hall.
Spoke at meeting of Federal Structure Committee on Government's decision to abandon Gold Standard.
Spoke at Guild House Church on "Voluntary Poverty".
Speaking at meeting of M.P.s elucidated idea of Complete Independence.
Had discussions with Aga Khan and Jinnah.
Had talks with representatives of cotton industry at Edgeworth and at Darwen.
Received deputation of unemployed workers at Springfield Garden Village.
Spoke at Adult School, West Bradford.
Received deputations from unemployed workers and Clitheroe Weavers' Association at West Bradford.
Had discussions with Sir Samuel Hoare.
Spoke at reception, Indian Chamber of Commerce, London.
Had meeting with the Aga Khan and other Muslim leaders at Ritz Hotel.
Speaking at Minorities Committee meeting, asked for its adjournment for a week.
Talked to Henry Carter on prohibition.
Independent Labour Party, Indian National Congress, League and the Gandhi Society arranged a birthday luncheon for Gandhiji at Westminister Palace rooms.
At Minorities Conference, London, Gandhiji opposed special representation to Depressed Classes.
Spoke at womem's reception arranged by Women's Indian Association at Central Y.M.C.A., London
Went to see C.F.Andrews at Canterbury.
Spoke at a meeting of Minorities Conference, London.
Attended party in honour of Lord Irwin.
Spoke at a meeting of Friends of India, London.
Presented Congress policy on minority question at Minorities Committee meeting.
Spoke at a conference of Missionary Societies in Great Britain and Ireland, London.
Gave interviews to Madame Montessori and Shaw Desmond.
Spoke at Federal Structure Committee meeting.
At National Labour Club said that India was determined to achieve Complete Independencem without shedding blood.
Explained communal question in interview to the Press.
Addressed Indian Students' meeting, Gower Street Hostel, Bloomsbury, London.
Gave interview to Joseph Bard, Editor, The Island, London.
Issued statement to the Press on solution of communal issue.
Had talks with Sir Samuel Hoare, Benthal and M.A. Jinnah.
Spoke at Federal Structure Committee meeting, London.
Spoke at meeting of students at International Students' Movement House, Russell Square, London.
Had talks with Samuel Hoare, T.B. Sapru, M.R. Jayakar and others.
Had discussion wth Callender on Mass Production v. Production by the Masses.
Spoke at Federal Structure Committee meeting and at Temperance Workers' meeting.
Spoke at Nottingham University College, Nottingham.
Gave interview to E.Wrench, Editor, The Spectator, London.
Spoke to Indians at Selly Oak, Birmingham, and exhorted them to return to India and serve their countrymen.
Spoke at Woodbrooke Settlement, Selly Oak, Birmingham on India's decision to attain freedom through peaceful means.
Spoke at Federal Structure Committee meeting, London.
Speech on "God is" (article printed in Young India dated 11-10-1928) was recorded by Columbia Broadcasting Company, London.
At meeting held under the auspices of the Royal Institute of International Affairs at Chatham House, London, spoke on "India of Today and Tomorrow."
Called on Lord Irwin and Col. Maddock.
Spoke at Federal Structure Committee meeting, London.
Spoke at Federal Structure Committee meeting, London.
Had a talk with T.B. Sapru and others.
Addressed a gathering of school Boys, Eton.
Left Eton in the morning for Oxford.
Spoke at meeting of Indian Majlis, Oxford.
Spoke on child education at Montessori Training College, London.
Spoke at a meeting of Commonwealth of India League, Central Hall, Westminister.
Spoke at meeting of Quakers at Friends' House, London.
Spoke at Pembroke College, Cambridge, reiterating his faith in a partnership of India and Britain on equal terms.
Submitted written statement at Federal Structure Committee, London
Spoke at the annual meeting of Children's House, Bow
Spoke at Federal Structure Committee meeting, London.
Spoke at meeting of Postal Workers' Union.
Mr. and Mrs. George Bernard Shaw called on Gandhi.
Declared in Press statement that he had cancelled his continental engagements.
Spoke at meeting, organized by Fellowship of Reconciliation at Friends' House, London.
Had talks with T.B. Sapru and others.
Discussed with J.M. Sen Gupta situation in Bengal.
Spoke at London School of Economics.
Explained his concept of Provincial autonomy at conference of the RTC delegates.
Spoke at Commonwealth of India League, London.
Sent a message to F.B. Fisher expressing his inability to visit America.
Spoke on defence at the Federal Structure Committee meeting.
Spoke at meeting of Women's Indian Council at Morley College, London.
Spoke on "Commercial Discrimination" at Federal Structure Committee Meeting.
Had discussions with Prime Minister, Lord Sankey, State Secretary, Sapru and Lees-Smith.
Made two speeches on "Provincial Autonomy" and on "Finance" in Federal Structure Committee meetings.
Met Dr. Ambedkar in the evening.
Participated in proceedings of Federal Structure Committee meeting.
Particiapted in Federal Structure Committee meeting.
Took part in proceedings of plenary session of RTC.
Gave interview to the Press, London.
Participated in proceedings of plenary session of RTC.
Delivered concluding speech at plenary session of RTC.
Released statement to the Press on events in India.
Gave interview to Sir Philip Hartog.
Had discussions with J.F. Horrabin, Wrench, Laski, Kingsley Martin, Brailsford and Nevinson.
Called on Prime Minister and Secretary of State for India.
